The Buddha said: In the past, there were hundreds of deer in a herd, following the good grass, encroaching near the human village. The king went out hunting, and they scattered in all directions.
There was a pregnant deer mother who went alone, chased, hungry and tired, losing her companions and feeling dejected.
At that time, she gave birth to two fawns. She left to search for food, feeling lonely and at a loss, falling into a hunter's trap. She cried out in grief, wanting to escape but unable to do so.
The hunter heard the sound and went to look. Seeing the deer, he was delighted and wanted to kill it.
The deer then kowtowed and pleaded, confessing:

'I recently gave birth to two fawns who are still young and ignorant. They are just looking around, not yet understanding east and west. I beg for a short while to return and see my fawns, to show them water and grass so they can live, and then return to die without violating my promise.'
At that time, the hunter heard what the deer said, and was greatly surprised.
He then replied to the deer:
'All people in the world are not even sincere, let alone you, a deer.
From death you have escaped, how could you return?
I will never let you go.'
The deer replied:
'If you listen, the fawn will live, if you stay, the fawn will die. Mother and child will die together, not being able to live apart. Divided, the child will die, ending three severe pains.'
Then he spoke a verse in reply to the hunter:
My body is a beast, roaming in the forest,
Despicable life coveting my body and life, unable to deliberately send myself to death.
Now coming into your trap, I will surely go to the knife and chopping block,
Not sparing this foul and stinking body, but only pitying my two fawns.'
The hunter, hearing what the deer said, was very surprised and unusual.
His mind still greedy, he replied to the deer:

'Deceit is unreal and cunning is hard to believe. Empty flowers are myriad and crafty is not one. Those who love their bodies and value their lives are few who can sacrifice themselves. It is still difficult to make an appointment with a heartless person, let alone an animal that has left, how can it return?
I will definitely not release you, so there is no need for many excuses.'
The deer then shed tears and replied in verse:
Although my body is a lowly animal, I do not understand human principles.
How can I accept your kindness, once I leave, I will not return.
It is better to endure the pain of being torn apart, than to remain as a false and deceitful existence.
I feel sorry for my two young ones, I beg for a short moment.
If there are evil people in the world, who create discord among the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha,
Destroy stÅ«pas and Buddhist temples, and kill arhats,
Betray and harm their parents, siblings, and spouses;
If I do not return, my crimes will be greater than these.
At that time, the hunter, hearing the words of the deer again, was even more shocked and sighed:

Only I, living in the world, was born as a human, yet I am foolish, deluded, and ignorant, turning my back on kindness and violating righteousness. I harm sentient beings and make a living from hunting and killing. I deceive and obtain things, greedily seeking without shame, not knowing impermanence and not distinguishing the Three Jewels.
The words of the deer are extraordinary compared to humans. His oath is profound, and his sincerity is evident in the middle.
He then went forward, untied the trap, and released them to leave.
Then the mother deer came to where her fawn was, lowered her head, neighed, licked the body of her fawn, both sad and joyful, and spoke a verse, saying:
All kindness and love come together, all due to causes and conditions uniting.
When they unite, there will be separation, impermanence is difficult to last for long.
Now I am your mother, always fearing I cannot protect myself.
Born in the world, there are many fears, life is as fragile as morning dew.
Then the doe mother, taking her two fawns to show them good water and grass, with tears flowing in two streams, immediately spoke a verse, saying:
I went out in the morning and did not meet with good fortune, mistakenly falling into the hunter's hands,
I will then be slaughtered, my body crushed and transformed into rotten meat.
Thinking of you coming to beg for mercy, I will now return to die,
Feeling pity for you being young and orphaned, make effort to live on your own.
After the doe mother spoke, she immediately left.
The two fawns cried out sadly, following behind and chasing after her, falling down and getting up again.
The mother looked back and ordered them, saying:
You return, do not come!
Do not let mother and child die together.
I am willing to die;
It is a pity that you are not yet aware that in the world, impermanence all has separation.
I myself have little fortune, and you were born with little blessings. Why grieve and pity, only increasing sorrow and trouble? Just be diligent in your practice and end your faults.
Then the mother deer spoke this verse to her child:
I was previously greedy and attached, and now I have come to be reborn as an animal.
In life, all have death, there is no escape from the suffering of the end.
Controlling the mind, being free from greed, only then is there great peace.
It is better to die with sincerity and faith, than to deceive and endanger life.
The child still wept and mourned, following each other, to the place of the hunter's snare, searching east and west.
He saw the hunter lying under a tree.
The mother deer stood in front of him and spoke a verse to awaken him:
The deer that were previously released have now come back to die.
Out of foolish and lowly attachment, I was able to see and say goodbye to my two children.
As I was about to leave, I showed them water and grass, and told them of impermanence and suffering.
I will die without any regrets, remembering their kindness, I dare not betray them.
The hunter suddenly woke up in a start. The deer again knelt before the hunter and repeated the verse, saying:
You let me go before, your virtue is heavier than heaven and earth,
A lowly animal was nurtured with kindness, I return to my death in faith.
I am moved by your kindness and cannot forget it, I dare not disobey your command,
Although I bear a thousandfold gratitude, it is still not enough to repay your kindness.

The hunter saw that the deer was faithful to the truth of death, his resolve was sincere, and his compassionate practice arose from the depths of his heart. He responded to the signs and fulfilled his vow to give up his life. The mother and child were grief-stricken and followed him to his death.
Moved by compassion, he bowed and apologized, saying:
You are a divine being of heaven, your faith and righteousness are so wonderful,
I am afraid and terrified, how could I dare to harm you?
I would rather kill my own relatives, crush my body and my wife and children,
How could I bear to harm a divine spirit, even with a thought as small as a hair?
The hunter then released the deer and let it go.
The mother and child, sad and happy, cried out in a cry, and in verse thanked the hunter:
As a lowly animal living in the world, I should be filling the kitchen.
I should be cooked and boiled right away, but I am given leave and spared for the sake of my two children.
The heavenly benevolent one values and loves things, and I am further pardoned and released.
My virtue and blessings are accumulated beyond measure, and cannot be expressed by the mouth.

At that time, the hunter told the king in detail, and the people of the country all knew that they were moved by compassion and faith. The deer's benevolent conduct had a metaphor for righteousness, and none did not respectfully sigh!
They stopped killing and hunting.
Then the deer returned to their herds and flocks, and roamed and gathered together, each at ease in their place.
